title: Iacchei Lab
text:
Welcome to the Iacchei Lab!








The Iacchei Lab is an academic research laboratory at Hawai’i Pacific University. Our lab uses a combination of field and molecular techniques to answer conservation and fisheries questions important to our local community.
See what our students are up to here
Click here to see the Iacchei Lab in the news
Find out more about our research here






August Spotlight
School starts August 25th! Our second year graduate student, Alondra Reyes, presented at the MSMS Student Symposium on August 22nd.
*insert picture of Alondra here




This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites, visit the official documentation.



 Back to top

title: Sophi Samus
text:
Sophi graduated from Hawai‘i Pacific University with a B.S. in marine biology where she worked on a number of projects including barcoding lobster phyllosoma samples and sorting plankton tows. She is now in the Master of Science in Marine Science (MSMS) program at HPU in the Iacchei lab. Sophi is primarily interested in the evolutionary impacts of climate change on intertidal invertebrates. Her thesis will investigate differential gene expression between endemic Hawaiian limpets (’opihi) in normal and stressed conditions. After she graduates, she plans to pursue a PhD in marine ecology, furthering her masters research.
Contact: ssamus1@my.hpu.edu

title: Jonathan Lin
text:
Jonathan graduated from the University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC) with a B.S. in marine biology. During his time at UCSC, he interned for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Fisheries Ecology Division, researching how ocean conditions influence fecundity in rockfish species. He is currently pursuing his Master of Science in Marine Science at the Hawai‘i Pacific University in the Iacchei lab. Jonathan is interested in analyzing the DNA in gut content of flying fish to understand their diet.


 Back to top

title: Hikari Bauson
text:
Hikari is an undergraduate student pursuing a B.S. in Marine Biology with a minor in Music at Hawai‘i Pacific University. She is currently working on extracting and processing DNA from flying fish and their gut content. Hikari is interested in studying marine invertebrates, especially worms in the phylum Annelida for her senior capstone. She hopes to gain more experience in lab settings after graduation and is looking into pursuing a Master’s Degree.
Contact: hbauson1@my.hpu.edu


 Back to top

title: Alondra Reyes
text:
Alondra graduated from Hawai‘i Pacific University with a B.S. in marine biology in 2024. As an undergraduate she worked on projects including sorting plankton tows, DNA barcoding mullets, megalops, and lobster phyllosoma samples in the Iacchei lab. She is currently pursuing a Master of Science in Marine Science at HPU. Her research focuses on the early larval stages and dispersal of lobster phyllosoma in the Hawaiian Archipelago. By integrating morphological measurements with DNA barcoding she aims to improve the accuracy of species identification for phyllosoma and reveal spatio-temporal patterns in spiny and slipper lobster species.
Contact: areyes20@my.hpu.edu

title: Klara Sobotikova
text:
Klara graduated from Hawai‘i Pacific University with an M.Sc. in Marine Science in 2025, where she studied the relationship between Pocillopora meandrina (cauliflower coral) and cryptofauna—tiny fish and invertebrates that live between the coral’s branches around Hawai‘i. Her research interests include coral adaptation to increasing ocean temperatures and changing water chemistry, and how knowledge of coral resilience can be applied to future restoration efforts. During her studies, she volunteered at the DAR Hawai‘i Coral Restoration Nursery and assisted with the Ciguatera poisoning project in the Iacchei Lab. She is now pursuing a Ph.D. in Evolution and Marine Biology at the University of Rhode Island under the supervision of Dr. Hollie Putnam, focusing on genetic traits in corals that affect their survival in the changing environment.
Contact: klara.sobotikova@gmail.com


 Back to top

title: Veronika Pearson
text:
Veronika graduated from Hawaiʻi Pacific University (HPU) Cum Laude with a B.S. in Marine Biology in 2025. Her research was focused on how toxin producing dinoflagellates varied across the coastal regions of Oahu. Her research utilized spatial analysis and Bayesian modeling of multiple potential environmental drivers on dinoflagellate cell density. After graduating, she continued studying dinoflagellates by working as a research technician to conduct the molecular identification of the dinoflagellate biodiversity sampled on Oahu. She now plans to further her education by pursuing a masters degree. 
Contact: vpearson1@my.hpu.edu




 Back to top

title: Mylou Matur
text:
Mylou graduated from Hawaiʻi Pacific University (HPU) Summa Cum Laude with a B.S. in Marine Biology. Her research focus was the influence of environmental conditions on the densities of toxin-producing dinoflagellate species associated with ciguatera poisoning on Oʻahu, Hawaiʻi. She was awarded a grant through the HPU Undergraduate Infrastructure Student Research Center (HUISRC) Health Research Concepts Competition (HRCC), served as an IDeA Networks of Biomedical Research Excellence (INBRE) Student Research Experience Intern/Associate, and her research poster won first prize at the INBRE 2025 Undergraduate Research Symposium. After graduating, she continued studying ciguatera poisoning as a research technician, shifting her focus toward molecular ecology. She now plans to join the Peace Corps as a Water Sanitation and Hygiene Education Facilitator in Peru.
Contact: mmatur@my.hpu.edu


 Back to top

title: Research
text:
Larval Dispersal and Recruitment


Over 85% of marine species have a bi-phasic lifestyle with an adult phase which is relatively sedentary compared to the larval or juvenile phase, which move far offshore and disperse thousands of kilometers to find new settlement habitat or to escape nearshore predators during this vulnerable life stage. Understanding the dynamics of this larval phase can determine seasonality of reproduction and recruitment, the connection between different locations or identify barriers between populations and inform which areas constitute sources of juveniles – areas of high reproductive output, and which areas are sink populations – locations where many juveniles arrive and recruit. Examples of previous and ongoing projects include: using a DNA barcode to identify larval fishes in Kāneʻohe Bay across a two different years to investigate how larval fish recruitment varied in different regions of the bay and search for recruits of culturally important food fishes; using DNA barcoding to identify the species crab megalops – the final larval stage prior to settlement in their adult habitat to species - to investigate lunar, seasonal and regional patterns in recruitment of different crab species along the Kona Coast of Hawaiʻi Island while searching for elusive larval recruits of the Kona crab; DNA barcoding for species identification and morphological aging of lobster phyllosoma larval stages to understand where the six species of spiny and slipper lobster travel across the Hawaiian Archipelago over their 6 to 12 month larval dispersal time period to identify sources and sink populations of these important recreational and subsistence fishery species.



Models of trophic dynamics are crucial to predicting impacts of fishing, environmental change, introduced species, and other anthropogenic impacts to ecosystems. Predator diets provide key insights into trophic interactions, but the prey of many marine species is not readily identifiable morphologically especially for prey that do not contain any hard parts that persist in the guts for a long time. By barcoding and metabarcoding the gut content of a variety of marine species we can reveal a broader scope of their diet, and in turn the relative importance and connection among species throughout the tropic web. Examples of previous and ongoing projects include DNA barcoding and metabarcoading of opah (moon fish) diets across the range of the Hawaiian tuna fishing fleet to understand niche partitioning across the epipelagic and mesopelagic zones in big-eye versus small-eye opah; investigating diets of aku (skipjack tuna) across the adult size range to assess whether there are ontogenetic (size or age-based) shifts in diet or if there are spatial differences in feeding preference; metabarcoding of seabird guano and barfs (metabarfcoding) to understand foraging behavior and diet of multiple seabird species in Hawaiʻi; DNA metabarcoding of gut contents of multiple flying fish species in Hawaiʻi and the North Pacific to understand the targeted prey of these key intermediaries connecting secondary consumers and top predators
Understanding trophic interactions through the lens of predator diets




Monitoring ecological communities across space and time, to understand how they are responding to environmental change and other anthropogenic impacts

All environmental survey techniques have advantages and disadvantages in terms of the types of organisms they detect and can effectively monitor. Using environmental DNA (eDNA) allows us to track many taxa that are not traditionally observed with classical in-field survey approaches. By using different gene regions we can target different organisms and tailor ecological surveys to specific questions and species. Example projects include working with school kids on Hawaiʻi Island to survey fish species by taking water samples from the shallows along their coastline;

title: Amelia Hart
text:
Amelia graduated from Hawaiʻi Pacific University (HPU) with a B.S. in Marine Biology in 2025.  During her time as an undergraduate, she worked closely with Iacchei Lab graduate student Sophi Samus on her project studying the response of an endemic Hawaiian limpet (ʻopihi Makaiauli) to heat stress. Based on this experience, Amelia focused her senior capstone research on analyzing the thermal limits and distribution of ʻopihi to understand how climate warming will impact their populations. Amelia plans to continue working with Sophi in her research efforts while also pursuing a career in marine conservation. 
Contact: melhart46@gmail.com


 Back to top

title: Roberta Cardenas
text:
Roberta graduated from Hawaiʻi Pacific University with a B.S. in Marine Biology where she worked in the Iacchei lab. Her capstone project focused on DNA barcoding of megalops larvae from West Hawaii to understand patterns in larval recruitment. She is now pursuing a Master’s in Biology, focusing on Arctic Marine Ecology, at the Arctic University of Norway (UiT). Her thesis will focus on how climate change potentially impacts trophic interactions between Calanus spp. copepods and the spring phytoplankton bloom in Kongsfjorden, Svalbard. After she graduates, she hopes to continue her education by pursuing a PhD in marine ecology. 

Contact: rocar6439@uit.no


 Back to top

title: Savannah Laliberte
text:
After growing up in Pittsburgh Pennsylvania, Savannah moved to Hawai‘i in August of 2015 to pursue a Bachelor’s degree in Marine Biology at Hawaiʻi Pacific University. During her time as an undergraduate at HPU, she was a voluntary laboratory assistant on the Seabird Tissue Archival and Monitoring Project (STAMP), a collaboration between the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and HPU to investigate environmental contaminants in seabird eggs. In addition to that, she participated in the Our Project in Hawaii’s Intertidal (OPIHI) internship through the University of Hawai‘i, Manoa Campus. During this internship, she used stable isotopes as a tool to examine mullet food web dynamics in Heʻeia Fishpond. 
Building upon her work done during the OPIHI internship, she decided to continue her education with HPU’s Master of Science Marine Science Program (MSMS). Her research focused on assessing mullet recruitment on a spatiotemporal scale within Kāne’ohe Bay. Savannah has a passion for conducting science with a purpose that will push the boundaries of scientific knowledge, while also producing results that are directly tangible to local Hawaiian communities and the public.
